instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00292: What is 820-00292? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00134: What is 820-00134? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
Hello,

I have an iMac with a faulty motherboard it seems. None of the LED light indicators are on and I confirmed that 12V is being provided by the power supply. I also replaced the power supply to rule it out. Seems to be failing very early in the boot process and I am wondering how can I start with the troubleshooting.

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
You should get at least S5 LED on.
Check <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> FET voltages.
Let us know which schematic used, for more details.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
I checked the voltages for <TRANSISTOR>Q8470</TRANSISTOR>.

<SIGNAL>FET_EN_P12V_S5_R</SIGNAL> = 21.6 volts (pin 4)
<SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL> = 12.4 volts (pins 1, 2, 3)
<SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.4 volts (pin 5)

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5 volts
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0 volts?

I am using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00134</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> schematic.

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP>
- <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_FET_P12V_S5_SSD_K</SIGNAL> -> EN1 = 4.4 volts (for 3.3 volt S5 enable)
- <SIGNAL>REG_VIN_U7600</SIGNAL> = 12.44 volts
- <SIGNAL>REG_P3V3_S5_OUT</SIGNAL> = 0 volts (0.117 resistance to ground)
- <SIGNAL>PM_EN_REG_P5V_S4_R</SIGNAL> -> EN2 = 0.4 volts (for 5 volt S4 enable)
- <SIGNAL>REG_P5VS4_VOUT</SIGNAL> = 0 volts

<CHIP>U7620</CHIP>
- <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> = 12.44 volts
- <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P3V3_S5_NON_SSD</SIGNAL> = 0 volts

Does this mean a faulty <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>? I hope this is not the case as I am not sure where to get an <CHIP>ISL6238</CHIP> chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
ISL62383C fails a lot.
Be sure to get "C" version!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
I replaced the ISL62383C and I get 3.8 volts on the enable pin, but no <SIGNAL>REG_P3V3_S5_OUT</SIGNAL>. VIN = 12 volt still. I am not sure what I am missing, could there be something else? Perhaps <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR> has failed as well? According to the spec it should be a positive voltage and I see about 1V.

Now I have an interesting issue. the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is gone. I confirmed my soldering is ok so not sure what happened. Maybe the ISL62383C chip I soldered is faulty?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at LDO5 (pin 18).
If good, then this ISL62383C is bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
I replaced the ISL62383C and it looks like LDO5 pin 18 is kind of back at 4.4 volts. VIN is no longer 12v but 4.4v. Am I just getting bad chips?

I also just re-read your reply. If diode mode is good (high resistance), then the chip is bad? It was a low resistance (0.070 or so) and thought chip was faulty so I replaced it. I misunderstood, but I am getting 4.4 volts now?

<SIGNAL>REG_P3V3S5_VOUT</SIGNAL> is 0.5 volts and resistance is 0.100. Is resistance normal?

EDIT: <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL> is now gone from the power supply - I think it just failed. Does the PSU have to be connected to the motherboard to provide 12V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
You can use lab PSU to power the board in repair process.

<SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> comes from <TRANSISTOR>Q8470</TRANSISTOR>, not directly from the power supply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
After some troubleshooting, I found a short on <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR>. Replaced it and also replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and now I have 12V back. I didn't get <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> which = 0.6 v. Injected voltage and found short on <CHIP>U3781</CHIP>. Removed and short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> is gone. However, I have a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. Injecting voltage draws about 0.9-1 amp from the PSU however I am unable to find anything heated. Looks like a direct short to ground somewhere. Any advice?

I also removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8440</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> and confirmed that there is no short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> as well as the two FETS themselves.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - A1419 Late 2015 iMac - No LED Lights
threads.message:
"I have a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>"
Exact ohm value of the short?
What voltage did you inject?
